body: @markusweimer @motus Could you please take a look at MockEvaluatorRequester.java? I'm having some compiler issues and do not understand why.
I have done a pass. It looks good. Should have a test to set the core or hello to show example and test the code pass.
LGTM. Will merge it.
@markusweimer I have addressed your review comments. Please have another look. Thanks!

> Should have a test to set the core or hello to show example and test the code pass.

How would we test this? If we run on YARN, we'd have to restrict the tests to clusters with large enough machines, right?
@jwang98052 I addressed your comments, Please have another look.

Welcome back, @tcondie! Since you've made your last REEF commit, things have changed a bit. Please have a look at the [contributor's guide](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/REEF/Contributing), especially the notes on [commit messages](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/REEF/Commit+Messages).

In essence, we start pull requests with a single commit which contains a commit message in the standard format.

Can you please rebase, squash and update the commit message?
@markusweimer Can you look at it again? I would really like it to be merged in before we make a branch for other work.
Can we set it to event 2 in Hello and run it as a test?
@jwang98052: This doesn't rebase cleanly to current `master`. Can you please do the rebase and test? I can merge thereafter.

> Can we set it to event 2 in Hello and run it as a test?

We can. But what do we do if the cluster doesn't have 2 core containers? Also, I don't know how to inquire how many cores we actually got to make sure the test passes. Any idea how to do that?
@motus @markusweimer Seems like AppVeyor and Travis are complaining about something that does not have anything to do with my changes. Could you please comment?

Yes, you can disregard those issues.
What you see on Travis is a jvm7 crashing on `ProtocolSerializerTest`. We have a JIRA item [REEF-1886](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1886) for it assigned to @dougmsft. 
On AppVeyor we have transient errors in IMRU fail path. It's been there for a long time (assigned to @jwang98052?)
@markusweimer I have rebased. Can you merge? Thanks!
@markusweimer Can you look at it again? More future changes will touch the same files in this PL. So I would like it to be merged before starting other JIRA to avoid conflict.
Also, please consider adding a `README.md` in the root folder of the new module that explains what it is and where to find the examples / tests.
Test failures are spurious will commit.-

You have build errors.

       "C:\projects\reef\lang\cs\Org.Apache.REEF.sln" (default target) (1) ->
       "C:\projects\reef\lang\cs\Org.Apache.REEF.Network.Examples.Client\Org.Apache.REEF.Network.Examples.Client.csproj" (default target) (24) ->
       "C:\projects\reef\lang\cs\Org.Apache.REEF.Bridge\Org.Apache.REEF.Bridge.vcxproj" (default target) (25) ->
       (ClCompile target) -> 
         InteropUtil.cpp(138): error C2146: syntax error : missing ';' before identifier 'JNIEnv' [C:\projects\reef\lang\cs\Org.Apache.REEF.Bridge\Org.Apache.REEF.Bridge.vcxproj]
         InteropUtil.cpp(138): error C4430: missing type specifier - int assumed. Note: C++ does not support default-int [C:\projects\reef\lang\cs\Org.Apache.REEF.Bridge\Org.Apache.REEF.Bridge.vcxproj]

You have build errors and multiple test failures.

       "C:\projects\reef\lang\cs\Org.Apache.REEF.Network.Examples.Client\Org.Apache.REEF.Network.Examples.Client.csproj" (default target) (24) ->
       "C:\projects\reef\lang\cs\Org.Apache.REEF.Bridge\Org.Apache.REEF.Bridge.vcxproj" (default target) (25) ->
       (ClCompile target) -> 
         InteropUtil.cpp(138): error C2146: syntax error : missing ';' before identifier 'JNIEnv' [C:\projects\reef\lang\cs\Org.Apache.REEF.Bridge\Org.Apache.REEF.Bridge.vcxproj]
         InteropUtil.cpp(138): error C4430: missing type specifier - int assumed. Note: C++ does not support default-int [C:\projects\reef\lang\cs\Org.Apache.REEF.Bridge\Org.Apache.REEF.Bridge.vcxproj]
Hmm, that looks like a C++ error that has nothing to do with the PR change. Is the master branch broken, too? I'll check and try to fix it tomorrow as soon as I get back to my Windows PC
The odd part is that the build is successful on VS 2017. I wonder if VS 2013/215 were updated?
Could this be because of the recent changes to the bridge?

@markusweimer that's what I would suspect, but I don't remember if we've pushed any of these changes to the master yet. All our bridge fixes must be in [dougmsft:REEF-1763](https://github.com/dougmsft/reef/tree/REEF-1763) branch. Please give me a few hours to figure it out

Ok, the breaking change likely comes from PR #1385, which had been merged into master 10 days ago. My guess is that the earlier versions of VSC++ do not recognize the `thread_local` keyword. I've created JIRA issue [REEF-1909](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1909) and assigned it to @jwang98052 -- Julia, could you please take a look?

**P.S.** I don't think this problem should prevent us from merging PRs #1391 #1392 #1393 #1394 #1395 #1396 #1397 which are all minor fixes to our Java code (but we need them for our TCP bridge work).
Okay I will commit.

@motus I completely understand your desire to get fixes in ASAP. But generally speaking build breaks can mask test failures (which would have happened if the build succeeded and tests were ran). We already have big enough problem with people completely ignoring CI results (as shown by https://github.com/apache/reef/pull/1385). It would be really nice not to encourage the few remaining people who actually look at CI failures to ignore them :-)
I will add it into yarn test once .Net change is made. Other than it, LGTM. I will test and merge.

Thanks Sergey for looking into it. I have submitted PL #1398 <https://github.com/apache/reef/pull/1398>  for REEF-1909<https://na01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fissues.apache.org%2Fjira%2Fbrowse%2FREEF-1909&data=02%7C01%7CQiuhe.Wang%40microsoft.com%7C1a362f441d5244a72de008d5172330c2%7C72f988bf86f141af91ab2d7cd011db47%7C1%7C0%7C636440362265677203&sdata=R4VTxkl5DxCIvjyypHCL8%2BzHbdMu9QXO424p9wyGjGI%3D&reserved=0> with the fix. The VS 2003 build has passed. Please have a look.

Thanks,
Julia

Has `TestResubmitEvaluator` test been failing before? It fails in all three builds, I don't remember it in the transient test failures but it's been a while since I looked at it

I will look at it.

I am seeing a test failure when I build locally which I am investigating.

@tcNickolas it looks like `TestResubmitEvaluator` consistently fails in current master. I can reproduce the failure on my PC in VS2017. I've opened [REEF-1910](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1910) issue in JIRA to track the problem and assigned it to @jwang98052 temporarily. I will test and merge *this* PR, though - at least it reduces the number of test failures
I have synced to apache master to pick up the recent fixes and am retesting. If the tests pass I will commit.
I will sync this request to apache master and it all tests pass, I will commit.l
I will sync this request to apache master, and if all tests pass, I will commit.

This is the test failure I am seeing on the C# side after syncing to Apache master. Is this currently expected or not?

Org.Apache.REEF.Tests.Functional.FaultTolerant.TestResubmitEvaluator.ResubmitEvaluatorOnLocalRuntime

@dougmsft Yes, this test currently fails in master. I've opened a JIRA for it yesterday: [REEF-1910](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1910). It is currently assigned to @jwang98052 :)
Okay it is going in.
Same resubmit evaluator test failure as main. Will commit.
Same test failure as master. Pulling to test and commit.

We have not pushed any bridge changes to apache master. The only work we have pushed to apache master is a number of framework classes that manage to message and blocking callers to from an asynchronous API. The changes to the actual bridge are all still in my clone of REEF.
Same test failure as master will commit.
Same test failures as in master. Will commit.
LGTM, will test and merge.
LGTM. Merging.
@motus Do you still have any comments about it?
@jwang98052 I think I have a few very minor ones. I'll post one last quick review tomorrow morning and will be ready to merge your code immediately after that.

@motus I fixed the bug (I believe). The test contained a race condition between unblocking the thread waiting for the new status and the thread fetching it. I fixed it by joining the waiting thread before fetching the result. in 100k repetitions on my box, this did not fail.
This seems to have worked. All tests on Travis pass now.
Only one test failure now which matches main. Will commit.

Regarding the comments "_You don't need to bind for DriverStatusHTTPHandler. This is for HttpServerReefEventHandler binding only. It is the unique one for entire server. For all the implementations of HttpHandler, REEF code will automatically detect all such handlers."_, I removed this comment that is the reason you could not reply :). It is true for HttpHandlers in .net, where the code will auto detect all the HttpHandlers and register them. But for httpHandlers in Java, you still need to bind it to the driver configuration. That is correct.

@jwang98052 this is a part of the [REEF-335](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-335) effort; the new bridge itself is a pretty good test for this functionality, but we can add more unit tests later in separate PRs
Cool, so it works :)

I run two times on yarn, driver was successful in the end, but not sure why the state it received in the end is always UNKNOWN_EXITED. As it does receive INIT and RUNNING, means FetchDriverStatus works.

Thanks for running it @jwang98052!

> I run two times on yarn, driver was successful in the end, but not sure why the state it received in the end is always UNKNOWN_EXITED. As it does receive INIT and RUNNING, means FetchDriverStatus works.

This state is reached because nothing prevents the Driver from shutting down before it can send `DONE` to the Client. If the Client has reached the Driver before, but can't reach it now, we know that the Driver was running and is no longer running. Which is the only thing the `public` API of this PR promises.

Of course, we should revisit this and provide more insight into the status of the Driver in the future as you suggested elsewhere on this PR. Just as soon as we finally find the time to work on a REEF.NET Client :)
I will merge it.

Another thing about `TestHelloREEFClient` - it failed in a [recent AppVeyor build](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/ApacheSoftwareFoundation/reef/build/2021-master/job/pb5dv3q0acn1g6xe/tests) (and in [the build](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/ApacheSoftwareFoundation/reef/build/2032-master/job/2aafs4ivnxs5af22/tests) for this pull request as well) because xUnit tries to execute it in parallel with other functional tests and they compete for the jar file. It has to have `[Collection("FunctionalTests")]` (same as all other tests which inherit from `ReefFunctionalTest`) so that xUnit knows to run them all sequentially, not in parallel.

Hi @markusweimer ! Thanks for the review!

I like the `set of folders` approach. In the technical implementation, however, I went with a `List` because `Tang`'s `Sets` require that you add items one-by-one to the configuration, but I couldn't find a way to specify that before I know the content of the sets. `Lists` do present the challenge that there could be multiple of the same item specified, but that is dealt with in the `FileSets` implementation.

I ended up allowing a list of files and folders to keep with the previous implementation.
Thanks for the review, @motus! I have addressed the issues raised.
